entry.title: We Played Small World and the Flavor Was Bittersweet
entry.content:
dragon master elves?!

Last Friday we hit up a small pub table and inconspicuously played J’s copy of Small World, “the fun, zany, light-hearted civilization board game!”

Designed by Philippe Keyaerts as a fantasy follow-up to his award-winning Vinci™, Small World is inhabited by a zany cast of characters such as dwarves, wizards, amazons, giants, orcs and even humans; who use their troops to occupy territory and conquer adjacent lands in order to push the other races off the face of the earth. (via)

This game has some disturbing colonialization themes aside; there are even pre-existing people in some territorites that you must conquer to inhabit that territory. Even so, I enjoyed this game so much that I eyed it hungrily at Card Kingdom after our party dispersed. The delicious flavor! The cool (albeit almost entirely white) characters! I love that the game naturally becomes different each time as you mix “race powers” and “special powers;” I love that the flavor of the game itself, its pictures and words, are delicious and meaningful and fly off the cardboard and became us — as in the terrifying era of K’s Pillaging Skeletons, uprooting their femurs from mountain and farmland and laying waste across nests of Flying Trolls and Berserk Humans, resting for only a moment before rising again in greater number. What.

One weak part of the game, however, are the victory points. They are called gold; if you have the most of them at the end of the game, You Win. Flavor-wise, I don’t feel like they entirely fit — when, during all this conquest, does gold arbitrary rise from the depths? — and there’s also not much that you can do with them, other than occasionally exchange them to get the race you want. During the “conquest” phase, they are useless. What if instead you could use them to do something like increase your number of troops, and gamble to try and get more land? What if you needed to pay coins in order to roll for reinforcement, an action that is otherwise totally free and something you usually want to do? It seems like a missed opportunity for logistical gameplay, and allowing players the pleasure of “not simply doing something, but doing it well — optimizing it to perfection.”

A also noted that, though he felt he had made the right “decisions,” he still placed last in our group of four, and didn’t grasp how he could have played the game better. He didn’t feel that he had “gained experience” and learned how to play the game any better. Though I can’t find it now, it reminds me of what I have read once regarding Triple Town, and how it seems to be a simple game until you make a mistake — and then you get it, you get what the game is about, you feel excited to give it another go.

smallworld board, getting all exciting as stuff accumulates

I hope to try out the expansions sometime, though the use of “gypsy” as a race in one of them is disconcerting, and reminds me of how uncomfortable the overall theme is.

entry.title: Some Thoughts Re: Thomas Was Alone
entry.content:
(via)

Thomas Was Alone was super cute, if more ambiguous than I personally like. I liked the personality given to all the different shapes, though their common heroism and conceit got a little old as the game went on, which was why Laura’s cynicism made her my favorite (though I felt compelled inexlicably to keep calling her “Ruth”). I loved that the levels were tilted, the play of light, the strange colors. (Though I wonder if any colorblind users had a hard time playing?)

One thing I think the game could have been improved was the game’s sense of progression; though numbers ticked up each level, after a while they became meaningless, and now that the game is finished I’m not totally sure what I would use them for. The introduction of each of the colored shapes, Thomas’s “death,” and the era of the gray shapes seemed to be the largest movements in the story, and though each was accompanied with a fun snippet of “The AIs are gaining sentience!” flavor I didn’t really have a sense that things were reaching their end until the end came suddenly to meet me. Some levels seemed like little “drabbles” and experiments, which I completed without much more effort than would take for me to click a cow in Farmville, and it would have been cool to see something else related to AIs breaking their previous ways of being. Breaking through the borders of levels — intentionally disobeying orders — something to add to the flavor text.

I played Thomas Was Alone on a projector and if you have the opportunity to do so yourself I recommend it. All those rectangles are like way better when they’re as big as your face.

entry.title: Lone Survivor & Meaningfulness
entry.content:
0.

Lone Survivor was the game I was most excited to obtain through a Humble Indie Bundle months ago, because the big grainy pixels looked so delicious, so fat with mood and atmosphere. And weirdness! And mysteriousness!

Spoilers ahead.


1.

One of my favorite parts of adventure games is the characterization that rises through interaction with items. Do characters like a certain item, or dislike it? Does the item bring up deep heartbroken memories of the past? How do they parse and react, and what does their rumination say for who they are? I'm reminded of Nancy Drew's endearing enthusiasm for lifting up random objects ("This plastic DNA model will be useful!") and Phoenix Wright's skeptical amusement when things like puppies are added to his inventory.

The most interesting item in the game for me was the toy cat, which I enjoyed petting all the time to accrue invisible "sanity" points. Engaging with the cat toy in particular puts you in the shoes and brain of the lone survivor himself, tinkering with a plush at the end of the world, just to have something light-hearted to do.



2.

Speaking of the cat plush, I loved the detail of this game — the unidentifiable flesh-like substances stretching across the wall — the way your map was dark unless you viewed it under sources of light — the specific food items like Delicious Ham, the creepy bottomless repositories of pills and Rotten Meats.



3.

A criticism of Lone Survivor seems to be that it was not scary enough. I played it at the height of summer and even then it was plenty terrifying, even if most of my stress and fear stemmed from being unable to hoard my bullets as obsessively as I would have liked.

Another scary part: putting your hand in that horrifying pink-red flesh-pixel hole. I really did not want to do that.


4.

The dream sequences were cool, and the characters therein intriguingly surreal, which I loved. Ultimately, however, I didn't feel that these scenes contributed to a larger understanding of what was going on, which was disappointing. Rather than deep, the first ending I received was vague, and a letdown. After carrying and caring for this dude I'd wanted a little more than a whiff of a broken heart. I wanted to know more about what this girl meant to the protagonist, how her departure left his life with zombie-filled corridors.


5.

I got my ending by playing as paragon as possible. I wanted to see if other endings would give me closure, so I found them on Youtube. Each one seemed vaguer than the last, and didn't interest me that much. I don't have a particular love of multiple endings and for me it's because they lack impact: I've only rarely encountered any set that comfortably resolves all issues and tension introduced in the game, and the way that such endings are reached never quite seems to match the decisions you made to get there.

In the case of Lone Survivor, the decisions that you make add to an invisible calculator which eventually spits out one of these endings: for example, killing more monsters gives you endings that imply you're mentally unstable. But why? What is it about killing these things makes you this way? The worst ending can also be achieved not just by killing monsters, but "eating food when not hungry or hurt" and "sleeping for no reason" (per this wiki). What's that connection?


6.

This was my other favorite part: getting that white cat to come live with me. I guess it's strange to be saying that after my demands for meaningfulness, since other than the invisible points, hanging out with the cat doesn't reveal any more of the protagonist's inner story. But playing with the cat, I felt for the first time that I was doing something in the game that I personally wanted, like it was really me in there, and not me poking through things in a dude-shaped glove.

Come here! Come here, little digital thing!

come and be with me forever

(source)

entry.title: Off the Leash
entry.content:
is the cutest dog-based tilt runner game that I've ever played, despite being a game in which it is difficult to play and get a screenshot which captures the excitement of running full tilt (ohoho) with a growing pack of thickly-lined canines. I only wish that there was a shiba inu, but then, I always wish this for everything, even things that don't necessarily include dogs in the first place.


screenshot of "off the leash"

It's free to play, with purchaseable items being more (non-shiba) dogs, power-ups, and even a permanent "2x coin bonus" thing for 99 cents.  At some point I unlocked "Tiki Surf Hut Bonus Thing Level" and searched around for it in vain, only to realize that its appearance would be a semi-random in-game occurrence, not something that I could summon at will from the main menu.  Was this an example of "verbal, unexpected, informational feedback" that is so beloved of games that hold high the ideal of instrinsic motivation?  Or maybe just UI that wasn't clear enough in informing me that it would reward me with such a bonus level after collecting X amount of steaks and Y number of dalmations during play?  The world may never know.

the crash of 38 dogs

entry.title: My Purple-y Play-through of Dear Esther
entry.content:
I played Dear Esther last week, which shouldn't be a surprise since Everyone Is Talking About It.

a screenshot near Dear Esther's opening

Playing it felt like being in a dark ride -- the level guides you along paths worn or fenced, and occasionally you get a glimpse of the "aerial," framed between giant stone features. Going the long way to examine scenery inevitably brings you back to the golden path, which is nice, because backpedaling would have been painful in a game with no running.

No running means that there's no way to rush through anything. In some ways being forced to slow down is comforting; rushing has been ingrained in me, rush to wake up, to get to work, to get back, to do homework. But in this game taking your time is coerced, is allowed. You can slow down to look at the cyan particle spray of ocean waves hitting the shore, to look at the rot-scarred timbers framing stone steps clotted with yellowbloom brush, to look at the mysterious luminescent chemical bonds and electrical diagrams splattered on the walls.

a screenshot containing one of those creepy candles that never melted

I have to admit that more than once I wanted to do more than look. I wanted to pick up the Bible on the ground and see what pages were bookmarked, I wanted to pick up medical instruments from trays of bloody water. Which is, I guess, why I felt like this game was so much of a dark ride: you play, sitting in your cart, immersed but unable to touch anything.

I guess one advantage of being unable to interact with things is that there's less pulling you from the immersion of the environment -- what would picking up a Bible have looked like, after all? Like a book rising from the ground and opening magically inches from your eyes? After a while I would have taken it for granted, but something so blatantly game-like would have been jarring the first time, would have reminded me that this world is a game. A couple times your character acts on his or her own -- near the beginning, you duck to avoid an impromptu seagull -- when you enter dark places, your flashlight flickers on, wordlessly. At moments like these it was easy to think that you the player were actually perched on the optic nerves of a very un-curious person, hallucinating a Bri'ish narrator and their descent into madness.

A feature of this game is that, though voice-overs are triggered as you make your way to certain areas, some are selected randomly to play, making for a story whose gem-glass plot-points feel jagged, don't quite fit together, rupture your reason-making. It could make the game an interesting one the second time around, I guess -- that random number generator might dole you out a new snatch of calming Englishman script. Though I want to consume all the text related to this story, I'm not quite tempted to play it over again, at least not just yet.

In conclusion: it's cool that Dear experimental Esther is being received so well! I'm glad to see people open to the new and unconventional things that video games can express, though there is some argument whether Dear Esther is a Real Game or not.

Other articles about Dear Esther to check out: Ludodiegesis, or Pinchbeck's unified field theory of FPS games, or "please pee on my leg and tell me it's raining.", Dear Eisenstein, On Dear Esther
